items.title: US senators take step towards ending longest government shutdown in history
items.standfirst: The US Senate on Sunday advanced a bill to end the government shutdown after some Democrats agreed to drop demands for an immediate extension of health care subsidies, angering others in their party. Lawmakers voted 60-40 in a procedural step toward passing compromise funding legislation, with final approval expected in coming days.
items.content: The US Senate on Sunday advanced a bill to end the government shutdown after some Democrats agreed to drop demands for an immediate extension of health care subsidies, angering others in their party. Lawmakers voted 60-40 in a procedural step toward passing compromise funding legislation, with final approval expected in coming days.

items.title: US Senate vote marks step towards ending federal shutdown
items.standfirst: Senators vote on advancing House-passed stopgap funding bill, suggesting end to historic 40-day shutdown in reachThe US Senate on Sunday took a key vote on a bill that would end the record-setting federal government shutdown without extending the healthcare subsidies that Democrats have demanded.Senators began voting on Sunday night to advance House-passed stopgap funding legislation that Senate majority leader John Thune said would be amended to combine another short-term spending measure with a package of three full-year appropriations bills. Continue reading...
items.content: Senators vote on advancing House-passed stopgap funding bill, suggesting end to historic 40-day shutdown in reachThe US Senate on Sunday took a key vote on a bill that would end the record-setting federal government shutdown without extending the healthcare subsidies that Democrats have demanded.Senators began voting on Sunday night to advance House-passed stopgap funding legislation that Senate majority leader John Thune said would be amended to combine another short-term spending measure with a package of three full-year appropriations bills. Continue reading...

items.title: Watch: Thune says he's hopeful government shutdown will end ahead of vote on key funding bill
items.standfirst: Senate Majority Leader John Thune said he was "hopeful that we can finally bring the shutdown to an end" ahead of a vote to advance a key funding bill. At least eight Democrats said they would back the deal.
items.content: Senate Majority Leader John Thune said he was "hopeful that we can finally bring the shutdown to an end" ahead of a vote to advance a key funding bill. At least eight Democrats said they would back the deal.

items.title: US Senate nears vote on bill that could end 40-day government shutdown

items.content: Centrist Democrats strike deal to reopen government but without a guaranteed extension of healthcare subsidies.

items.title: Sanders, Schumer speak out against deal to end shutdown, emphasize health care fight
items.standfirst: Sens. Bernie Sanders and Chuck Schumer spoke out against a funding deal that has the support of at least eight Democrats, which could end the government shutdown. Both senators emphasized the health care fight and rising costs for Americans.
items.content: Sens. Bernie Sanders and Chuck Schumer spoke out against a funding deal that has the support of at least eight Democrats, which could end the government shutdown. Both senators emphasized the health care fight and rising costs for Americans.

Oil prices rose in early trading, supported by progress toward ending the US government shutdown.
Moderate Senate Democrats moved to end the government shutdown, abandoning their 40-day standoff.
Democratic lawmakers reacted strongly to the Senate deal, expressing deep divisions within the party.

items.title: BBC in crisis: why did Tim Davie and Deborah Turness resign?
items.standfirst: Director general and head of news quit amid accusations of bias over Trump and trans issues at broadcasterBBC director general resigns – latest updatesThe BBC director general, Tim Davie, and head of news, Deborah Turness, resigned dramatically on Sunday night after accusations that the corporation was failing in its duty of impartiality. The chair of the board, Samir Shah, is expected to apologise on Monday for the way in which a speech by the US president, Donald Trump, was edited in an episode of Panorama. The show is one of a number of examples highlighted by Michael Prescott, a former external adviser to the BBC’s editorial standards committee, who detailed his concerns about the broadcaster’s impartiality in a memo published by the Telegraph. Continue reading...
items.content: Director general and head of news quit amid accusations of bias over Trump and trans issues at broadcasterBBC director general resigns – latest updatesThe BBC director general, Tim Davie, and head of news, Deborah Turness, resigned dramatically on Sunday night after accusations that the corporation was failing in its duty of impartiality. The chair of the board, Samir Shah, is expected to apologise on Monday for the way in which a speech by the US president, Donald Trump, was edited in an episode of Panorama. The show is one of a number of examples highlighted by Michael Prescott, a former external adviser to the BBC’s editorial standards committee, who detailed his concerns about the broadcaster’s impartiality in a memo published by the Telegraph. Continue reading...

clusters.title: LIVE: Syria’s Ahmed al-Sharaa to meet Donald Trump at the White House
clusters.neutral_headline: Syrian president to hold talks with Trump at White House

items.title: LIVE: Syria’s Ahmed al-Sharaa to meet Donald Trump at the White House
items.standfirst: Ahmed al-Sharaa to become first Syrian president to visit the White House in nearly 80 years.
items.content: Ahmed al-Sharaa to become first Syrian president to visit the White House in nearly 80 years.

items.title: From jailed jihadist to the Oval Office: Syria's president caps unlikely rise with Trump meeting
items.standfirst: Syrian interim President Ahmed al-Sharaa will meet with President Donald Trump in Washington on Monday.
items.content: Syrian interim President Ahmed al-Sharaa will meet with President Donald Trump in Washington on Monday.

items.title: Syrian president to hold talks with Trump at White House
items.standfirst: Ahmed al-Sharaa is expected to push for full lifting of remaining sanctions imposed during 13-year civil warSyria’s president, Ahmed al-Sharaa, will on Monday hold talks with Donald Trump at the White House, the first such official visit by a Syrian leader since national independence in 1946. He is expected to push for a full lifting of the remaining sanctions on his war-ravaged country.Sharaa, whose Islamist rebel forces toppled the longtime ruler Bashar al-Assad late last year, has courted the US president to try to reverse the economic restrictions imposed during the 13-year civil war, arguing they are no longer justified. Continue reading...
items.content: Ahmed al-Sharaa is expected to push for full lifting of remaining sanctions imposed during 13-year civil warSyria’s president, Ahmed al-Sharaa, will on Monday hold talks with Donald Trump at the White House, the first such official visit by a Syrian leader since national independence in 1946. He is expected to push for a full lifting of the remaining sanctions on his war-ravaged country.Sharaa, whose Islamist rebel forces toppled the longtime ruler Bashar al-Assad late last year, has courted the US president to try to reverse the economic restrictions imposed during the 13-year civil war, arguing they are no longer justified. Continue reading...

items.title: From US enemy to ally? Why ex-jihadist Syrian president's meeting with Trump is a big deal
items.standfirst: It is a moment few could have imagined just a few years ago but the Syrian president, Ahmed al Sharaa, has arrived in Washington for a landmark series of meetings, which will culminate in a face-to-face with Donald Trump at the White House.
items.content: It is a moment few could have imagined just a few years ago but the Syrian president, Ahmed al Sharaa, has arrived in Washington for a landmark series of meetings, which will culminate in a face-to-face with Donald Trump at the White House.

items.title: Syrian president al-Sharaa arrives in US for landmark White House visit
items.standfirst: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in the US on Ssturday where he is due to meet with President Donald Trump at the White House – the first such visit by a Syrian president since the country's independence in 1946. Ahead of al-Sharaa's visit the leader was removed from the US terrorism blacklist. Shirli Sitbon has this story.
items.content: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in the US on Ssturday where he is due to meet with President Donald Trump at the White House – the first such visit by a Syrian president since the country's independence in 1946. Ahead of al-Sharaa's visit the leader was removed from the US terrorism blacklist. Shirli Sitbon has this story.

items.content: The Syrian leader will meet the US President at the White House on Monday for security talks.

ai_summary: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa will meet with President Donald Trump in Washington.
This is the first official visit by a Syrian leader since the country's independence in 1946.
Al-Sharaa is expected to push for a full lifting of remaining sanctions on Syria.
Al-Sharaa's Islamist rebel forces toppled Bashar al-Assad late last year.
The Syrian leader was removed from the US terrorism blacklist before the visit.

clusters.title: Typhoon Fung-wong leaves 4 dead and 1.4 million displaced in the Philippines
clusters.neutral_headline: Typhoon Fung-wong leaves 4 dead, 1.4 million displaced

items.title: Typhoon Fung-wong leaves 4 dead and 1.4 million displaced in the Philippines
items.standfirst: Typhoon Fung-wong blew out of the Philippines after setting off floods and landslides, knocking out power to entire provinces, killing at least four people and displacing more than 1.4 million.
items.content: Typhoon Fung-wong blew out of the Philippines after setting off floods and landslides, knocking out power to entire provinces, killing at least four people and displacing more than 1.4 million.(Image credit: AP)

items.title: Philippines typhoon aftermath: 'Water levels are rising fast'
items.standfirst: A weakened Typhoon Fung-wong is now passing over the South China Sea, after leaving two people dead in the Philippines.
items.content: A weakened Typhoon Fung-wong is now passing over the South China Sea, after leaving two people dead in the Philippines.

items.title: Weather tracker: Typhoon Fung-Wong becomes second in a week to hit the Philippines
items.standfirst: Destructive winds and rainfall hit archipelago, while a cold spell in Florida prompts fears of falling iguanasTyphoon Fung-Wong, locally known as Uwan, is the second in a week to affect the Philippines after making landfall on Sunday evening. The weather system prompted warnings for heavy rainfall and life-threatening storm surges across much of the country, with sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of about 140mph recorded on Sunday by the national meteorological agency.By the time Fung-Wong moves past the Philippines early this week, more than 200mm of rainfall is expected to have fallen on Luzon, the country’s most populous island. Continue reading...
items.content: Destructive winds and rainfall hit archipelago, while a cold spell in Florida prompts fears of falling iguanasTyphoon Fung-Wong, locally known as Uwan, is the second in a week to affect the Philippines after making landfall on Sunday evening. The weather system prompted warnings for heavy rainfall and life-threatening storm surges across much of the country, with sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of about 140mph recorded on Sunday by the national meteorological agency.By the time Fung-Wong moves past the Philippines early this week, more than 200mm of rainfall is expected to have fallen on Luzon, the country’s most populous island. items.title: More than 1 million evacuated in the Philippines as Typhoon Fung-wong makes landfall
items.standfirst: At least two people found dead as super-typhoon hits Philippines, days after Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 224More than 1 million people have been evacuated from their homes in the Philippines and at least two people have been killed as Typhoon Fung-wong – the second big storm to hit in days – made landfall on the east coast.The super-typhoon crossed over the north of the archipelago’s most populous island, Luzon, with torrential rain, sustained winds of 115mph (185km/h) and gusts of up to 140mph (225km/h). Continue reading...

clusters.title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy may be released from prison
clusters.neutral_headline: Nicolas Sarkozy seeks release from prison pending appeal

items.title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy may be released from prison
items.standfirst: Camille Knight has more.
items.content: Camille Knight has more.

items.title: Defiant Sarkozy says prison life is ‘very hard’ as he seeks release from jail – Europe live
items.standfirst: Former president is seeking to be released pending his appeal against a five-year sentence for criminal conspiracyAs we are waiting for the Paris court decision on Sarkozy to come, expected around 13.30 local time (12.30 GMT), let’s take a look at other news across Europe.If Sarkozy gets released with an ankle tag, it won’t be his first: Reuters notes that last year, France’s highest court upheld a separate conviction for corruption and influence peddling, ordering him to wear an electronic tag for a year, a first for a former French head of state. The tag has now been removed. Continue reading...
items.content: Former president is seeking to be released pending his appeal against a five-year sentence for criminal conspiracyAs we are waiting for the Paris court decision on Sarkozy to come, expected around 13.30 local time (12.30 GMT), let’s take a look at other news across Europe.If Sarkozy gets released with an ankle tag, it won’t be his first: Reuters notes that last year, France’s highest court upheld a separate conviction for corruption and influence peddling, ordering him to wear an electronic tag for a year, a first for a former French head of state. The tag has now been removed. Continue reading...

items.title: Nicolas Sarkozy says life in prison is ‘gruelling’ and ‘a nightmare’
items.standfirst: Former French president was talking to court via video link about his request to serve rest of sentence at homeEurope live – latest updatesThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has said his time in prison has been “gruelling” and a “nightmare” as he appeared by video link at a court hearing over his request to be released and to serve his sentence at home.Sarkozy, dressed in a navy blue suit, appeared on camera from prison on Monday, seated at a table with his lawyers beside him. He told the court: “I want to pay tribute to all the prison staff, who are exceptionally humane, and who have made this nightmare bearable – because it is a nightmare.” Continue reading...
items.content: Former French president was talking to court via video link about his request to serve rest of sentence at homeEurope live – latest updatesThe former French president Nicolas Sarkozy has said his time in prison has been “gruelling” and a “nightmare” as he appeared by video link at a court hearing over his request to be released and to serve his sentence at home.Sarkozy, dressed in a navy blue suit, appeared on camera from prison on Monday, seated at a table with his lawyers beside him. He told the court: “I want to pay tribute to all the prison staff, who are exceptionally humane, and who have made this nightmare bearable – because it is a nightmare.” Continue reading...

items.title: Paris court to hear Sarkozy’s request to be freed from jail pending appeal
items.standfirst: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy's request to be released from prison pending appeal will be heard by a Paris court Monday less than three weeks after the ex-head of state began serving a five-year prison sentence for conspiring to raise campaign funds from former Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi.
items.content: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy's request to be released from prison pending appeal will be heard by a Paris court Monday less than three weeks after the ex-head of state began serving a five-year prison sentence for conspiring to raise campaign funds from former Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi.

items.title: French prosecutors request Sarkozy's supervised release from jail pending appeal
items.standfirst: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy's request to be released from prison pending appeal will be heard by a Paris court Monday less than three weeks after the ex-head of state began serving a five-year prison sentence for conspiring to raise campaign funds from ex-Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi. Prosecutors requested that Sarkozy be released under judicial supervision.
items.content: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy's request to be released from prison pending appeal will be heard by a Paris court Monday less than three weeks after the ex-head of state began serving a five-year prison sentence for conspiring to raise campaign funds from ex-Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi. Prosecutors requested that Sarkozy be released under judicial supervision.

items.title: France: Paris court to rule on Sarkozy's release
items.standfirst: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy is set to learn the outcome of his appeal for release. Tomorrow, Monday, starting at 9:30 am, the Paris Court of Appeal will review the request submitted by his lawyers. What criteria will the court take into account, and in what form could his release be granted? Daniel Quinlan reports.
items.content: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy is set to learn the outcome of his appeal for release. Tomorrow, Monday, starting at 9:30 am, the Paris Court of Appeal will review the request submitted by his lawyers. What criteria will the court take into account, and in what form could his release be granted? Daniel Quinlan reports.

ai_summary: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy is seeking release from jail.
Sarkozy is appealing a five-year sentence for criminal conspiracy.
Sarkozy described prison life as "gruelling" and a "nightmare".
A Paris court will hear Sarkozy's request for release on Monday.
Sarkozy began serving his five-year sentence less than three weeks ago.

clusters.title: Iran: Dams almost empty in Mashhad, home to 4 million people
clusters.neutral_headline: Iran Drought: Water Levels Drop in Mashhad Dams

items.title: Iran: Dams almost empty in Mashhad, home to 4 million people
items.standfirst: Water levels at the dam reservoirs supplying Iran’s north-eastern city of Mashhad have plunged below 3%, according to reports, as the country suffers from severe water shortages. Director of the United Nations University for Water, Environment and Health, Kaveh Madani, gives his insights on this critical drought in Iran.
items.content: Water levels at the dam reservoirs supplying Iran’s north-eastern city of Mashhad have plunged below 3%, according to reports, as the country suffers from severe water shortages. Director of the United Nations University for Water, Environment and Health, Kaveh Madani, gives his insights on this critical drought in Iran.

items.title: Water levels below 3% in dam reservoirs for Iran’s second city, say reports
items.standfirst: Storage dwindles in Mashhad, home to 4 million people, as country struggles with droughtWater levels at the dam reservoirs supplying Iran’s north-eastern city of Mashhad have plunged below 3%, according to reports, as the country suffers from severe water shortages.“The water storage in Mashhad’s dams has now fallen to less than 3%,” Hossein Esmaeilian, the chief executive of the water company in Iran’s second largest city by population, told the ISNA news agency. Continue reading...
items.content: Storage dwindles in Mashhad, home to 4 million people, as country struggles with droughtWater levels at the dam reservoirs supplying Iran’s north-eastern city of Mashhad have plunged below 3%, according to reports, as the country suffers from severe water shortages.“The water storage in Mashhad’s dams has now fallen to less than 3%,” Hossein Esmaeilian, the chief executive of the water company in Iran’s second largest city by population, told the ISNA news agency. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Water storage in Mashhad's dams has fallen below three percent, reports indicate.
Mashhad, Iran's second-largest city, faces severe water shortages.
The city's water company chief executive confirmed the low water levels.
The country is experiencing a critical drought, impacting water supplies.
The United Nations University expert commented on the drought's severity.

clusters.title: Explosives and weapons seized - with 71 arrests - as Syria launches clampdown on Islamic State cells

items.title: Explosives and weapons seized - with 71 arrests - as Syria launches clampdown on Islamic State cells
items.standfirst: Syria has carried out pre-emptive operations targeting Islamic State cells - arresting 71 people during 61 raids.
items.content: Syria has carried out pre-emptive operations targeting Islamic State cells - arresting 71 people during 61 raids.

items.title: Syria carries out preemptive raids against Islamic State
items.standfirst: Security operations came as Syrian president Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in Washington to meet Donald TrumpSyria has carried out nationwide preemptive operations targeting Islamic State cells, a spokesperson for the interior ministry said on Saturday, as the country’s president arrived in the US for talks with Donald Trump.Syrian security forces carried out 61 raids, with 71 people arrested and explosives and weapons seized, the spokesperson told state-run Al Ekhbariya TV. Continue reading...
items.content: Security operations came as Syrian president Ahmed al-Sharaa arrived in Washington to meet Donald TrumpSyria has carried out nationwide preemptive operations targeting Islamic State cells, a spokesperson for the interior ministry said on Saturday, as the country’s president arrived in the US for talks with Donald Trump.Syrian security forces carried out 61 raids, with 71 people arrested and explosives and weapons seized, the spokesperson told state-run Al Ekhbariya TV. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Syrian forces conducted preemptive operations targeting Islamic State cells.
Seventy-one people were arrested during sixty-one raids across Syria.
Explosives and weapons were seized during the security operations.
The operations occurred as the Syrian president arrived in the US.
The interior ministry spokesperson announced the security measures.
